title: Quiz 2: Assessment, Admission & Ethics
description: Procedures for assessing critically ill patients, admission criteria, and managing ethical/legal dilemmas.

questions.question: According to the study material, what is the 'ICU Treatment Entitlement Index' (ICU E.I.) formula?
questions.explanation: Engelhardt suggested the formula: (Potential Benefit × Quality of Life × Remaining Length of Life) / Cost.
questions.hint: The formula aims to balance benefits against cost.

questions.question: Which of the following are valid criteria for admission to an ICU? (Select all that apply)

options.text: Patients needing extensive specialized nursing care
Patients with terminal illness and no hope of recovery

questions.explanation: ICU admits potentially recoverable patients needing monitoring, specialized nursing, or constant physician care. It is not for terminal care where treatment is futile.

questions.question: Informed consent implies the right of a patient to refuse treatment, even if it is life-saving.
questions.explanation: Informed consent includes the right to choose between alternatives and the right to refuse treatment entirely.
questions.hint: Can a competent adult say 'no' to a doctor?

questions.question: Read the case summary below. What was the legal outcome?

richContent.content:
Case: Baby K (1992)

An infant was born with anencephaly. The mother insisted on keeping the baby alive by all means, contrary to medical advice.

options.text: The courts ruled in favor of the physicians to stop treatment
The courts upheld the mother's right to demand treatment
The hospital ethics committee made the final decision

questions.explanation: Both the US District Court and Court of Appeal upheld the mother's right to demand treatment despite the diagnosis.
questions.hint: Courts often favor patient/guardian rights in such disputes.

questions.question: Arrange the steps of the ICU admission procedure in the correct logical order:
questions.explanation: The general procedure is to deal with the biological problem first (life-saving) before considering protocols like data collection or finances.

questions.question: Match the assessment finding to its potential indication:
questions.explanation: Cold skin indicates poor circulation; mental changes indicate cerebral issues; low urine indicates renal issues.
questions.hint: Connect the symptom to the affected system.

questions.question: The ___BLANK___ approach assesses the patient as a whole, rather than just a collection of biological systems.
questions.explanation: A holistic approach looks at biological, physiological, and sociological needs together.

questions.question: Which of the following are considered 'Critical Pathways' for categorization?
questions.explanation: Trauma, Sepsis, Coma, Cardiac abnormalities, and Over-dosage are listed as critical pathways. Elective surgery is a planned procedure.

questions.question: What is the term for when a patient is discharged against the doctor's recommendation?
questions.explanation: Discharge Against Medical Advice (DAMA) requires a patient to sign a declaration.

questions.question: It is ethically acceptable for a physician to make a unilateral 'do-not-resuscitate' decision without informing the family.
questions.explanation: Physicians fail their moral duty if they take unilateral decisions without informing patients/relatives. Bilateral consensus is required.
questions.hint: Consider the case of Catherine Gilgum.
